Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back with some modelling for head and clypeus, and simple incised divisions in single line for prothorax and elytra, and triangular winglets on either side; underside with incised schematic figure of a standing man holding a stick in his right hand; motif surrounded by incised single line; pierced lengthwise; in very bright light blue paste; in rather good condition but surfaces slightly worn.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The motif depicted on the base appears on some scarabs produced at Naukratis (on the various productions of the “Scarab Factory”, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a few versions of this motif (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 123-125). It can be found on glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids: BM 1886,0401.1677; Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis.14; Sydney, The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney NM00.128.9. This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially found in Cartage, Cumae and Perachora (Gorton 1996, 114-117, type XXXII, subtype A2-27a).
